title: On the inside of a metal water bottle - doesn't come out with ... - Reddit
body: Aluminum oxide, i.e. "rusted" aluminum. Normally containers like that are spin-coated, usually with a thin layer of polymer or epoxy- the reason people are concerned about BPA in their food containers is because some of the monomer may remain behind.
readable_content:
coolmandan03 (2014-02-02): On the inside of a metal water bottle - doesn't come out with soap or hot water. Water bottle has only been used for water

gerryfleck: mineral deposits? Try throwing some white vinegar in there and let it sit before rinsing it out.

- MrDorkESQ: It is probably a calcium/lime scale from hard water. Try filling it up with distilled vinegar and letting it soak for a day or two.

- americanaluminium: If its aluminum, its probably a small amount of corrosion. I have had several aluminum bottles do this. If its stainless steel it may be lime build up from hard water.

- IrekJanek: What kind of metal? Aluminum or stainless steel?

- handfulofsounds: Maybe something something something vinegar

- Leezardy: May be minerals from the water. If soaking it in 50/50 vinegar/water works, then it's that. Just rinse with plain water afterwards.
